content.description: Clip the first bolt 8 feet off the ground and continue up large holds on easy Terrain to a Ledge. Pull the Crux moves up a short steep dhedral followed by a short technical face move and onto large holds that will bring you to the anchor.
content.location: This route is located on the far left side of the Crag.

content.description: Currently the best route at the Crag and one of the finest in the area of the grade. Climb the Arete past multiple veins of bright quartzite. Pull onto a precarious block and onto a steep and enjoyable crux section. Large holds after the ledge will bring you to the anchor
content.location: This route is located 40 feet down Hill from the upper right end of the cliff.

climbs.name: People Get Up And Drive Your Funky Soul
climbs.fa: Daniel Lenel, Kelsey Gray, Nick Weicht

content.description: This route starts up the short dihedral and clips a Bolt ten feet off the ground. Climb up 25 feet  two an overhanging section of wall then continue through the first Crux sequence. Shake out on the right trending rap before embarking on the 2nd 20 foot overhanging technical section that will bring you to the quick link hanging on the point at the top of the cliff.
content.location: This route is located 30 feet downhill from the right end of the cliff.

content.description: Climb up a series of ledges to the first Bolt ten feet off the ground. Cross a low angle ramp and move up into a steep section of Rock that will bring you one too a large rights trending rap. Continue straight up over an interesting mantle move and on to the Anchor located at the High Point of the cliff. This route is a rope stretcher so be sure to use a stopper knot
content.location: This route is route starts where the approach Trail meets the Crag.

content.description: Clip the first Bolt 10 feet off the ground then climb through the tyrolean Traverse on low angled Rock. Pull through a 10 foot steep section to gain in a ramp then follow enjoyable face moves straight up to the anchor visible from the base of the climb.
content.location: This route is located six feet left of where the approach Trail meets the Crag and climb Fall line to a visible chain at the top of the cliff.

content.description: Caution long route! This climb starts off the nice flat belay Ledge and climbs low-angle rock to a first Bolt located 14 feet off the ground. Climb up a steep section of Cliff angling slightly right to gain the top of a Ledge. Follow this Arete section up to a crux move at a small overhanging section and on to the anchor.
content.location: This route starts off the nice flat belay ledge where the approach Trail meets the lowest point of the Crag.

content.description: This route starts off the approach Trail and scrambles up 12 feet to the first Bolt. Continue to follow the hangers passed a left slanting overhanging future. Continue up enjoyable train to the anchor.
content.location: This route is located on the left side of the Crag and starts to climb just after the beginning of the tyrolean Traverse.

content.description: Clip the first Bolt 8 feet off the ground on a steep section to gain a left trending ramp. Cross this and climb through a short overhanging feature and pull through a few more vertical sections with intermittent ledges to gain the anchor.
content.location: This is the first route located on the uphill side of the tyrolean Traverse.

content.description: This crag is located six hundred feet above the east end of the Valdez Airport runway and is the upper right cliff in a cluster of four.  A good approach trail has already been cut in to access Lookout Rock and the Panorama Point area.  The hike up here is AMAZING and well worth it even if the cliff is not yet finished.   Lookout Rock!! is a  project in the making so no anchors or bolts are currently on the wall.  It can be top roped off alders but be forewarned there are thousands of pounds of rock, dirt, and moss that still needs to be scrubbed and trundled off this face before it is ready for the normal climber.  If anyone wants to drag a shovel, pick, pry bar and a dozen wire brushes up to the wall and put in a few hundred hours of effort we'll have a new crag soon. If not I hope to invite you up some time in the fall of 2014 for some great new routes.
